title: Resource Annotator
introduction: Use the annotator tool to mark up each source and caption. You can use up to five pins for each theme.

themes.title: Identity
themes.tooltip_text: The qualities and beliefs of an individual.

themes.title: Culture
themes.tooltip_text: Shared beliefs, traditions, and practices of a group.

themes.title: Community
themes.tooltip_text: A feeling of wanting to be with other people or of caring about the other people in a group.

sources.title: Salmon Fry
sources.image_credit:
Image 1: Salmon Fry, Chief Leschi Schools, July 2016. Photographs by Doug McMains, 2016

Image 2: Women cooking salmon, Muckleshoot Reservation, ca. 1950. Photograph courtesy of the Museum of History and Industry, Seattle
sources.body:
Image 1: Roasting salmon over fire not only is delicious, but also reflects healthy, time-honored preparations of Native foods. Prior to the treaty times of the Pacific Northwest in the 1850s, Native foods did not include white flour or lard, two less healthy staples provided by the United States after treaties were ratified.

Image 2: These women were preparing skewered salmon over a fire pit around 1950. This type of traditional preparation is free of the additional fats that pan-frying requires. Salmon was the staple of traditional diets of Pacific Northwest Native people; researchers estimate that even as late as the 1940s, annual consumption was over 320 pounds per person.
sources.excerpt:
Image 1: Roasting salmon over fire not only is delicious, but also reflects healthy, time-honored preparations of Native foods. Prior to the treaty times of the Pacific Northwest in the 1850s, Native foods did not include white flour or lard, two less healthy staples provided by the United States after treaties were ratified.

Image 2: These women were preparing skewered salmon over a fire pit around 1950. This type of traditional preparation is free of the additional fats that pan-frying requires. Salmon was the staple of traditional diets of Pacific Northwest Native people; researchers estimate that even as late as the 1940s, annual consumption was over 320 pounds per person.
sources.question_text: In what other ways than nutritional benefits are traditional cooking methods important to Native individuals and communities?

sources.title: Shovel-nose canoe
sources.image_credit:
Image 1: Shovel-nose canoe, 1921. Duwamish Indians. NMAI N07289

Image 2: Duwamish shovel-nose canoe, ca. 1880–1910. Cedar, iron nails, and copper. Canoe of square-end type, used on lakes and rivers. King County, Lake Sammamish. NMAI 097294
sources.body:
Image 1: Shovel-nose canoes have been used for river fishing since time immemorial. The flat bottom allows for upriver navigation using poles. Fishers are able to sit at both the prow and stern.

Image 2: Shovel-nose canoes are flat bottomed and dug out or carved from a single tree. They are engineered for speed and agility in shallow waters. There is a growing trend among Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest to reestablish the making and use of shovel-nose canoes.
sources.excerpt:
Image 1: Shovel-nose canoes have been used for river fishing since time immemorial. The flat bottom allows for upriver navigation using poles. Fishers are able to sit at both the prow and stern.

Image 2: Shovel-nose canoes are flat bottomed and dug out or carved from a single tree. They are engineered for speed and agility in shallow waters. There is a growing trend among Native Nations of the Pacific Northwest to reestablish the making and use of shovel-nose canoes.
sources.question_text: What does the design of the shovel-nose canoe tell you about culture and the importance of knowledge of the environment in salmon fishing among Native people of the Puget Sound region?

sources.title: Lisa Wilson Cook
sources.body: “My dad instilled in me how important the fish was. We spent many hours out on the water, and that is how I related to myself, as a strong person through fishing . . . I know that I’m the person that I am today because of fishing.”
sources.excerpt: “My dad instilled in me how important the fish was. We spent many hours out on the water, and that is how I related to myself, as a strong person through fishing . . . I know that I’m the person that I am today because of fishing.”
sources.question_text: How can the relationships you have with family members inform your sense of identity?
sources.resource_caption: Caption: Lisa Wilson Cook is a water resources technician for the Lummi Nation and has a Bachelor of Science in Native Environmental Science. She reflects on reasons for which fishing is important to her identity.
